title: Girls being harassed by the League community
body: I posted a Reddit thread earlier about being harassed because my name is in my IGN, so people are aware that I am a girl. The people who commented on the thread reacted terribly, saying it was my fault for showing off that I am a girl. I shouldn't be told in detail how I'm going to be raped, or that I must be fat and ugly because I play. No one deserves that. I think Riot really needs to do something about this. http://www.reddit.com/r/leagueoflegends/comments/2i7bj3/as_a_girl_player_i_am_so_sick_of_the_league/

replies.body:
Hey Stephanie,

I am so sorry to hear about the kinds of things you have to put up with while playing League. As a lady, I understand the kinds of harassment that can get thrown at us so easily by strangers. 

All I can do is assure you that when you report players after a game, it does matter. Riot takes harassment very seriously, and our player behavior initiatives are working to weed out bad eggs. Anyone who thinks the type of behavior you described is acceptable has no place in our community. We will punish them and if they choose not to reform we will permanently ban them.

But I know that might be cold comfort so all I can do is apologize that you have had to put up with these kinds of behaviors. It would be a shame to lose you as part of the League community, we need all the ladies we can get!

Be sure to always report players. Pre and post-game chat *are* logged, though they were not visible in the original version of the tribunal. Your reports do matter!!
Thank you very much for your kind words! I will continue to report every time these things happen. I hope that as a community we can weed out the bad eggs together! :]

Those kind of actions should result in permanent bans. I've heard the pre and post game chats are not recorded, so be sure to take screenshots of those and submit tickets if you have to. It's unfortunate but ultimately there's little riot can do on their own about the community, it is up to the good part of the community to identify the problems and bring them to riot's attention. Only when we do this effectively can we expect riot to deal with them.
Thank you for an actual kind and sensitive comment. I didn't get a single one of those on Reddit. I will start keeping records with screen shots.

The upside of the internet:  Everyone is free to say whatever they want.  True freedom of speech in an anonymous environment so nobody can be punished for having unpopular or dissenting opinions and allows the free flow of information to be discussed among millions.

The downside of the internet:  Everyone is free to say whatever they want.  True freedom of speech in an anonymous environment gives a platform for bigots and assholes to spread prejudice and hatred while giving them an echo chamber of like-minded people assuring themselves they're 'correct.'

Yes, and no. 

They're free to say whatever they want, sure. Riot is also free to punish them however they want. 

"Just how it is right now" is a situation that could be fixed pretty quickly. Making a rape threat to another player should result in a permanent ban. And there really isn't any context that would make that situation okay, so there's no gray area here.

>The people who commented on the thread reacted terribly, saying it was my fault for showing off that I am a girl.

There's a distinction between establishing a causal relationship and attributing blame. If someone offers me a beverage with a tranquilizer and I drink it, I will be knocked out *because* I accepted a drink from someone untrustworthy. And yet, the fault lies with the asshole who gives people spiked drinks.

Obviously, somebody harassing you for any reason, gendered or otherwise, is unfortunate. The people in that reddit thread, however, seem to be making the relatively practical observation that a name change would reduce the harassment you receive - I don't see anyone making the normative claim that your name entitles others to harass you.

I don't really care either way, but it's a pretty important distinction to make.

Did you not read the top rated comment then?

>Maybe don't tell them you are a girl and stop replying to them? 

Or.. any of the comments? I don't see any of the tone appropriate for the suggestion, e.g. "I know it sucks but maybe you should consider a name change because it's easier to inconvenience yourself than fix other people." And I see a hell of a lot of "You're whining, you shouldn't "broadcast"* your gender if you care."

*Because summoners with "man", "dude", "bro" or all three in their name totally get discriminated against right?

>Maybe don't tell them you are a girl and stop replying to them?

Again - there is a distinction between practical advice and moral condemnation. In my analogy, a friend might rightly suggest that I shouldn't accept drinks from strangers. That suggestion in no way implies that it's not the fault of the person offering me a spiked drink, and it'd be dishonest of me to afterwards claim as much.

"Maybe don't accept drinks from strangers" is in no way synonymous with "It's your fault for accepting drinks from strangers," and claiming that it was for the sake of generating sympathy or getting attention would be both intellectually dishonest and incredibly rude to the person offering the advice. 

Similarly - "Maybe don't use a feminine name" is in no way synonymous with "It's your fault for using a feminine name," and claiming that it was for the sake of generating sympathy or getting attention would be both intellectually dishonest and incredibly rude to the person offering the advice.

A wife in the middle east is being beaten while you shop for groceries, and you don't even bat an eye. Ah, there's a difference in definitions going on here. Understandable.

I define sexist as 'drawing legitimacy from gendered narratives.' For instance, the stereotypical 'Get back in the kitched!' snipe is based on the premise that women stay at home while men work. Thus, it's sexist. Alternatively, the super chivalrous dude who tries to carry things for women because he believes women require the help is sexist, even if he isn't malevolent.

In this case, I think the application is dubious. My rewrites are grounded in the understanding that, if people in League of Legends know you're a girl, they'll be more likely to harass you. That's obviously an understanding that has to do with gender, but it's also a factual observation. 

If those posts were arguing something like 'girls *should* be harassed, so it's you fault for saying that you're a girl,' then yeah, that'd obviously be sexist. But like I said in my first post, you can make practical observations without simultaneously making normative claims.

It's kind of meaningless once the harassment/rape has already happened.

>By saying she can changed her name if she wants to avoid all this, you imply that because she hasn't changed her name, she doesn't want to avoid all this. That is sexist. Period.

These are all valid reasons to keep her current name, even if it's true that she'd receive less harassment with a more gender neutral name.
